titleStmt.title:
The Life and genuine Caracter of Dr 08. Swift dedicated
to Alexander Pope.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Wise Rochefoucault a maxim writ
made up of malice, Truth, and Wit
If what he says be not a joke
we Mortals are strange kind of folk
But hold, before we further go
'Tis fit the Maxim we should know
He says, whenever fortune sends
Disaster to our dearest friends
Althô we outwardly may grieve
we oft are laughing in our Sleeve
Amd wṇ I think upon't this minute
I fancy there is something in it
we see a Comrade get a fall
yet laugh our Hearts out one & all
Tom for a wealthy wife looks round
A Nymph that is worth ten thousand pound
He no where could have better pickt
A Rival comes, and Tom is nickt
See how behave his friends profest
They turn the matter to a Iest
loll out their Tongue & thus they talk
Poor Tom has got a plaguy Balk
I could give instances enough
That humane friendship is but stuff
Whenere a flattering Puppy cries
You are his dearest friend, he lyes
To loose a Guinea at Piquet
would make him rage, and storm, & fret
bring from his heart sincerer groans
then if he heard you broke your Bones
Come tell me truly would yụ take well
Suppose yṛ friend and you were equall
To see him always foremost stand.
Affect to take the upper hand.
And strive to pass in publick view
for much a better man than you
Envy I doubt would powerfull prove
and get the better of your Love
It would please yṛ Palate like a Feast
To see him mortify'd at least
'Tis true we talk of Friendship much
But who are they that can keep touch
True friendship in two Breasts, requires
The same Aversion, the same Desires:
My friend should have when I complain
A fellow feeling of my pain
Yet by Experience oft we find
Our friends are of different mind
And when I torture with the Gout 3}
they laugh to see me make a rout
glad that themselves could walk about
Let me suppose two special friends
and both to Poetry pretends
would either Poet take it well
to hear the other bore the Bell
His rival for the Chiefest reckon'd
Himself pass only for a second
When you are sick, yṛ friends you wḍ say
would send you howdees every Day
Alass that gives you small Relief
They send for manners, not for grief
nor if you dye would fail to go
that Evening to a Puppet show
Yet come in time to shew their Loves
to get a Hatband, Scarf, and Gloves
To make these Truths the better known
Let me suppose the Case my own
The Day will come when it shall be said
Did ye hear the news? The Dean is dead
Poor man he went all on a sudden
has droppḍ and given the Crow a Pudden
What was behind him found?
I hear, about two thousand pound
'Tis own'd he was a man of wit
yet many foolish thing he writ
Sure he must be deeply learn'd
That is more than ever I discern'd
I know his nearest friends complain
He was too airy for a Dean
He was an honest man I swear
why Sir I differ from yụ there
For I heard another Story
he was a most confounded Tory
yet have heard a strange Report
That he was well receiv'd at Court
Why then it was I do assert
their Goodness more than his desert
He grew or else his Comrade lyed
Confounded dull before he dyed.
He hoped to have a lucky hit
Some medals sent him for his wit
But truly there the Dean was bit
om.
om.
Must we the Drapier then forget
is not our Nation in his Debt
'Twas he that wrte the Drapier Letters
He should have left them for his Betters
We have a hundred abler men
nor need depend upon his Pen
Say what you will about his Reading
you never can defend his Breeding
Who in his Satyrs runing Riot
could never leave the World in Quiet
Attacking when he took the Whim
Court, City, Camp, all one to him
But why would he except he stobber'd
Offend our Patriot great Sir Robert
whose Counsels aid the Sovereign Power
to save the Nation every hour
what scenes of Evils he unravels
In Satyrs, Libels, lying Travels
Not sparing his own Clergy Cloath
But eats into it like a moth
He makes mankind as bad as Elves
I answer they may thank themselves
If Vice can never be abash'd
it must be rediculd or lash'd
But if Chance to make a Slip
what right had he to hold the whip
If you resent it, Who is to blame
He never knew yụ nor your Name
Should Vice expect to escape Rebuke
Because its Owner is a Duke
Vice is a Vermin Sportsmen say
No Vermin can demand fair play
om.
I envy not the Wits that write
meerly to gratifye their Spite
Thus did the Dean, his only Scope
was to be held a misanthrope
This into generall Odium drew him
which if he like much good may do him
This gave him Enemies in Plenty
Thrô two Realms nineteen in Twenty
His Zeal was not to lash our Crimes
But discontent against the Times
For had we made him timely Offers
to raise his Post or fill his Coffers
Perhaps he might have truckled down
Like other Brethren of his Gown
For Party he would scarce have bled
I say no more because he is dead
But who could charge unto his face
He ever cring'd to man in place
His Principles of ancient date
Ill suit with those profest of late
The Pope and Calvin he would oppose
And thought they both were equal foes
The Church and State had suffer'd more
By Calvin, than the Scarlet Whore
Thought Popish and fanatick Zeal
Both bitter foes to Brittain's weal
The Pope would off our faith bereave us
But still our Monarchy would leave us
Not so, the vile Fanatick Crew
That ruin'd Church and Monarch too
Suppose these Reflections just
We could indulge the Dean's disgust
who so the fractious Tribe caress'd
And Lovers of the Church disstress'd
Tha Patrons of the good old Cause
In Senates sit at making Laws
The most malignant of the herd
in surest way to be prefer'd
and Preachers find a better Quarter
for railing at the holy Martyr
whole Swarms of Sects with Grief he saw
more favour'd than the Church by Law
Thought Protestant too good a Name
For canting Hypocrites to claim
whose Protestation hides a Sting
Destructive to the Church and King
which might as well in his Opinion
become an Atheist or Socinian
A Protestant is a special Clinker
it serves for Sceptick and free thinker
it serves for Stubble Hay and Wood
for everything but wṭ it should
what writing has he left behind
I hear they are of different kind
a few in Verse but most in prose
some high flown Pamphlets I suppose
All Scribble in the worst of Times
to palliate his friend Oxford's Crimes
to praise Queen Ann nay more defend her
as never favouring the Pretender
or Libels yet conceal'd from sight
against the Court to shew his Spite
Perhaps his Travels part the Thread
Lye at every second Word
Offensive to a loyal Ear
But not one Sermon yụ may swear
Sir our Account are different quite
And your Conjectures are not right
tis plain his writings were design'd
to please and to reform mankind
om.
om.
om.
om.
|||Dṛ Swift.
